name: Dawat-E-Islami USA
mission: Ameer e Ahle Sunnat’s Mission: I must strive to reform myself and people of the entire world. ان شاء اللہ
zakatClaimEvidence: Dawat e Islami USA Inc. lists "Zakat" as a donation category on their online donation page. Their website explicitly states, "ZAKAT. Give Zakat, Spread Mercy: A Pillar of Faith, A Source of Blessing. Donate Now." Another page mentions, "Give your Zakaat to Dawateislami and support more than 80 departments". They also describe Zakat as "The practice of donating 2.5% of your eligible wealth annually to support less fortunate Muslims." (Source: https://www.dawateislami.net/donations/)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Limited match due to weaker results and/or higher uncertainty; review methodology details before deciding.

components.improvement_suggestion: Clarify zakat allocation policy and eligible use categories for donors.

alignment.rationale: Alignment 26/50: MEDIUM Muslim donor fit, religious cultural cause area

components.improvement_suggestion: If reserves are above policy target, document why and publish triggers for planned deployment.

components.improvement_suggestion: Seek external evaluation or track outcomes over at least 3 years.
components.name: Evidence & Outcomes

components.improvement_suggestion: Document a clear theory of change with an explicit causal pathway.
components.name: Theory of Change

risks.risk_summary: Key concern: Board too small: 2 members

risks.description: No outcome measurement or metrics tracking

score_details.score_summary: Dawat E Islami USA Inc shows moderate alignment and limited impact, with zakat compliance (significant risk deductions applied).

zakat.claim_evidence: Dawat e Islami USA Inc. lists "Zakat" as a donation category on their online donation page. Their website explicitly states, "ZAKAT. Give Zakat, Spread Mercy: A Pillar of Faith, A Source of Blessing. Donate Now." Another page mentions, "Give your Zakaat to Dawateislami and support more than 80 departments". They also describe Zakat as "The practice of donating 2.5% of your eligible wealth annually to support less fortunate Muslims." (Source: https://www.dawateislami.net/donations/)

all_citations.claim: Dawat E Islami USA Inc is registered as a 501(c)(3) organization focused on religious and educational programs.
The organization reported total revenue of $2,429,214, a program expense ratio of 96.4%, and 20.2 months of working capital.
The organization conducts religious activities and educational outreach.
Dawat-e-Islami produces literature focused on Islamic moral and cultural values.
The organization tracks the quantity of specific educational booklets printed as part of its outreach metrics.
The organization accepts various forms of donations, including Zakat, to fund its religious and charitable operations.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a moderate score due to its excellent financial efficiency and direct service model, though it is tempered by low data confidence and a lack of independent impact verification.
areas_for_improvement: Limited third-party impact data and low data confidence scores
Reliance on religious and cultural niche programming which may limit broader donor alignment

dimension_explanations.alignment: As a Zakat-eligible entity, the charity aligns well with donors seeking to fulfill religious obligations through traditional Islamic education and cultural activities [8]. However, the alignment score of 26/50 suggests a medium donor fit, as its mission is highly specialized toward specific religious and cultural urgency [3][4].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization focuses on direct provision of religious education through programs like Hifz Quran and the distribution of educational literature [2][5]. While it maintains a high program expense ratio of 96.4% and a cost per beneficiary of approximately $85.77, the overall impact score of 19/50 reflects a need for more robust evidence of long-term outcomes [1][2].

baseline_narrative.headline: Dawat E Islami USA Inc provides comprehensive religious and educational services with a strong focus on direct program delivery and financial sustainability.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 96.4%, indicating the vast majority of funds go directly to services
Exceptional fundraising efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised
Strong liquidity with 20.2 months of working capital
baseline_narrative.summary: Dawat E Islami USA Inc is a non-profit organization dedicated to performing educational, charitable, and religious activities, including specialized programs like Dar ul Madina and Hifz Quran [1][2]. In the 2023 fiscal year, the organization reported a total revenue of $2,429,214 while maintaining a high program expense ratio of 96.4% [2].

all_citations.source_name: Charity Navigator - Dawat E Islami USA

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a moderate score due to its excellent financial efficiency and direct service model, though it is tempered by low data confidence and a lack of independent impact verification.

areas_for_improvement.detail: The organization currently operates with a <cite id="1">board of only 2 members</cite>, which falls below standard recommendations for independent oversight.
There is <cite id="1">no verified third-party impact evaluation</cite> or documented theory of change to validate long-term outcomes.

bbb_assessment.summary: No BBB Wise Giving Alliance assessment is currently available for this organization.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization maintains high liquidity, which provides a safety net against short-term financial mismanagement.
risk_factors: <cite id="1">Board size of only 2 members</cite> creates concentration of power risks
<cite id="1">Low data confidence score (0.3)</cite> due to limited public transparency
case_against.summary: The primary concern is the <cite id="1">minimalist governance structure</cite> and lack of external impact validation.

confidence.notes: While financial efficiency is high, the low data confidence score stems from governance and transparency gaps.

alignment.explanation: Alignment is strong for Muslim donors as the org <cite id="8">accepts zakat</cite> and serves the <cite id="1">fi sabilillah asnaf category</cite>.
alignment.improvement: Clarifying the <cite id="8">zakat allocation policy</cite> would help donors better understand how their funds are partitioned between different asnaf.

credibility.explanation: Credibility is established through <cite id="1">96.4% independent board members</cite> and consistent filing, though data confidence is low due to <cite id="1">limited transparency and a small board size</cite>.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the charity should <cite id="1">expand its board to at least five members</cite> and publish audited financial statements.

impact.explanation: Impact is driven by a <cite id="1">96.4% program expense ratio</cite> and a low <cite id="1">cost per beneficiary of $85.77</cite> for religious services.
impact.improvement: The organization could improve its impact score by <cite id="1">tracking outcomes over at least 3 years</cite> and documenting a clear theory of change.

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Distributes funds to affiliated Dawat-e-Islami entities for program execution

rich_narrative.headline: Dawat E Islami USA Inc provides comprehensive religious and educational services with a strong focus on direct program delivery and financial sustainability.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who prioritize traditional Islamic education and masjid infrastructure and value a 96.4% program-spend model.
donor_motivations: Want to ensure 96.4% of their donation reaches the program
Value the preservation of traditional Islamic sciences (Hifz, Nazra)
Prefer supporting established religious movements with global reach
Seek to fulfill zakat through religious educational pathways
giving_considerations: The organization has a very small board which may limit independent oversight
Impact is measured by outputs (booklets printed, students enrolled) rather than long-term social outcomes
Financial transparency is limited compared to larger humanitarian peers
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking high-transparency organizations with large, diverse boards or those requiring independent RCT-level evidence of social impact.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects that while the organization tracks outputs like <cite id="5">printing 2,000 booklets</cite>, it lacks external evaluations of its educational efficacy.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: The organization operates on the premise that providing accessible religious education and prayer spaces leads to improved community moral standards and spiritual well-being.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that religious education programs are effectively meeting the spiritual and literacy needs of the students.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: With a <cite id="1">revenue CAGR of 5.4%</cite> and expanding global programs, the organization can absorb more capital for masjid construction.

organizational_capacity.geographic_reach: Pakistan, USA, Canada, UK, Korea, Australia, Bangladesh, Mozambique

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by a <cite id="1">96.4% program ratio</cite> compared to a <cite id="1">peer median of 89.1%</cite>.

similar_organizations.differentiator: More focus on convert care and social community spaces
similar_organizations.name: Ta'leef Collective

similar_organizations.differentiator: Larger board and more diverse local programming
similar_organizations.name: Islamic Center of Irvine

strengths.detail: The organization directs <cite id="2">96.4% of its expenses toward programs</cite>, significantly exceeding the <cite id="1">peer program ratio median of 89.1%</cite>.
The charity maintains <cite id="1">20.2 months of working capital</cite>, providing a substantial buffer for long-term operational stability.
The organization spends <cite id="1">$0.00 to raise every $1</cite>, ensuring no donor funds are diverted to marketing or solicitation costs.

strengths_deep_dive: Dawat E Islami USA's financial health is characterized by a rare combination of high liquidity and zero-cost fundraising. With <cite id="2">$2,429,214 in annual revenue</cite> and <cite id="1">96.4% of expenses dedicated to programs</cite>, the organization operates as a highly efficient pass-through for religious and educational services. Its <cite id="1">20.2 months of working capital</cite> suggests that the organization is not living 'hand-to-mouth' but has the strategic depth to sustain its <cite id="1">Masajid construction and Faizan Online Academy</cite> even during economic downturns.
rich_narrative.summary: Dawat E Islami USA Inc is a religious and educational non-profit that operates with a mission to perform <cite id="2">educational, charitable, religious, and cultural activities</cite>. The organization manages a diverse portfolio of specialized programs including <cite id="1">Dar ul Madina, Hifz Quran & Nazra, and the Faizan Online Academy</cite>, which focus on spiritual development and traditional Islamic literacy. Financially, the charity operates at a significant scale for its niche, reporting <cite id="2">total revenue of $2,429,214</cite> in the 2023 fiscal year. A defining characteristic of its financial model is its extreme leaness; the organization maintains a <cite id="1">program expense ratio of 96.4%</cite> according to its most recent financial filings, ensuring that nearly every dollar contributed is utilized for direct service delivery. This efficiency is further highlighted by a <cite id="1">fundraising efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised</cite>, suggesting that the organization relies on organic community support or volunteer-led efforts rather than paid solicitation. Beyond its educational centers, the charity supports <cite id="1">Masajid construction and specialized programs for Islamic sisters</cite>, reaching a global audience through its digital and physical infrastructure. While the organization demonstrates <cite id="1">strong liquidity with 20.2 months of working capital</cite>, its governance structure remains highly centralized, which is a critical factor for donors to consider alongside its high program output.
